Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Increased diurnal difference of NO<sub>2</sub> concentrations and its impact on recent ozone pollution in eastern China in summer.

AbstractText: Nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>) is a key tropospheric O<sub>3</sub> precursor. Since 2013, efforts to decrease air pollution in China have driven substantial declines in annual NO<sub>2</sub> concentrations, whereas ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) concentrations have increased. Based on nationwide NO<sub>2</sub> observations and a regional air quality model (WRF-CMAQ), we analyzed trends in the diurnal difference (DD, the difference between nighttime and daytime concentrations) of NO<sub>2</sub> concentrations across eastern China and in five national urban agglomerations (UAs) from 2014 to 2021, and explored the factors underlying such changes and the potential impacts on O<sub>3</sub> pollution. We found that the observed DD of NO<sub>2</sub> has increased in most cities and UAs, and that this trend can be primarily attributed to changes in anthropogenic emissions, based on comparison with DDs simulated with fixed anthropogenic emissions, which generally showed much weaker trends and little interannual variation. A sensitivity analysis using the WRF-CMAQ model was conducted to investigate the impact of a modified diurnal cycle of nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>) emissions on O<sub>3</sub> concentrations. The result revealed that enhancing the DD of NO<sub>2</sub> would increase O<sub>3</sub> concentrations in the morning and the daily maximum 8-h O<sub>3</sub> concentrations in the cities with high NO<sub>x</sub> concentrations, as well as downwind areas of cities, indicating that greater DDs in NO<sub>2</sub> is one of the reasons that have led to the enhanced China's O<sub>3</sub> pollution in recent years.
